channel.title: Attribute "final"
channel.description:
When declaring a default value, i.e: [code=java] public static final int MY_INT = 0; [/code]
should I be using "final"? I'll be using MY_INT as
[code=java] MY_INT += Entity.hit; [/code]
as a way of recording total damage for a player's character file. My understanding of "final" is use it if the object you're creating will never be altered, but this is forever changing.
I just want to know the OO way.

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“The Outsider, post:16, topic:423297”][quote author=t4 link=topic=525943.msg3830143#msg3830143 date=1322505733]
This is what I had in mind. I’ve meant to say Procedural Programming instead of Functional Programming - (not to be confused with mathematical functions, but similar to those used in functional programming) seems to be where my memory failed me.

Regardless, the point still stands. https://www.moparisthebest.com/origrs2/ can provide a few examples.
[/quote]
How many bloody types are there? Thanks for your informative replies.[/quote]
Very many, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_pattern_(computer_science) for more information.

Read full topic

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“The Outsider, post:14, topic:423297”][quote author=t4 link=topic=525943.msg3830113#msg3830113 date=1322504242]

Ironically, I’m studying a level 2 OOP course in Java…

For the record, I’m using Hyperion, and so what you’re saying is, as long as it’s readable, it doesn’t have to be perfect? Say I take functionality > design now, wouldn’t it ruin the “trend”?

If there’s no right or wrong, and OOP is just a standard if you like, the why is it so misconceived when people post code that isn’t indented perfectly?

I’m now very confused, because if there’s no right or wrong, I can go two ways… be more functional over design and save time, or keep trying to be OO and be safe from the “wank” as you so put it.

Object oriented programming is the design of your code (spacing, readability) or just safe, memory-leak-free, concurrent with disregard to whether I’m capitalizing my variables correctly or not.

What I thought I understood I now think I’m not to sure. Is it one of those things where it’s different for everybody? Like Marmite?

You’re in a course and don’t know what static and final modifiers do?

Do you not know what Functional Programming is?
[/quote]
I’m in a course not a job, lol. I’m also a month behind due to no fault of my own. I’m also starting at level 2 (didn’t do the level 1 introduction to Java as it was unavailable at my time of registration).

So I read the Intro and the Concept part of Functional Programming, when you mentioned it I assumed “Funtional - as in just working order”.

I interpreted the text from the link, from what I read, to be a more dynamic and complex style of programming, so say if you alter one thing, it doesn’t interrupt a hundred other lines of code? Basically?[/quote]
This is what I had in mind. I’ve meant to say Procedural Programming instead of Functional Programming - (not to be confused with mathematical functions, but similar to those used in functional programming) seems to be where my memory failed me.

Regardless, the point still stands. https://www.moparisthebest.com/origrs2/ can provide a few examples.

Read full topic

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @The_Outsider The Outsider
item.description:
@The_Outsider wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:13, topic:423297”][quote author=The Outsider link=topic=525943.msg3830112#msg3830112 date=1322504123]
Ironically, I’m studying a level 2 OOP course in Java…

For the record, I’m using Hyperion, and so what you’re saying is, as long as it’s readable, it doesn’t have to be perfect? Say I take functionality > design now, wouldn’t it ruin the “trend”?

If there’s no right or wrong, and OOP is just a standard if you like, the why is it so misconceived when people post code that isn’t indented perfectly?

I’m now very confused, because if there’s no right or wrong, I can go two ways… be more functional over design and save time, or keep trying to be OO and be safe from the “wank” as you so put it.

Object oriented programming is the design of your code (spacing, readability) or just safe, memory-leak-free, concurrent with disregard to whether I’m capitalizing my variables correctly or not.

What I thought I understood I now think I’m not to sure. Is it one of those things where it’s different for everybody? Like Marmite?
[/quote]
You’re in a course and don’t know what static and final modifiers do?

Do you not know what Functional Programming is?[/quote]
I’m in a course not a job, lol. I’m also a month behind due to no fault of my own. I’m also starting at level 2 (didn’t do the level 1 introduction to Java as it was unavailable at my time of registration).

So I read the Intro and the Concept part of Functional Programming, when you mentioned it I assumed “Funtional - as in just working order”.

I interpreted the text from the link, from what I read, to be a more dynamic and complex style of programming, so say if you alter one thing, it doesn’t interrupt a hundred other lines of code? Basically?

Read full topic

For the record, I’m using Hyperion, and so what you’re saying is, as long as it’s readable, it doesn’t have to be perfect? Say I take functionality > design now, wouldn’t it ruin the “trend”?

If there’s no right or wrong, and OOP is just a standard if you like, the why is it so misconceived when people post code that isn’t indented perfectly?

I’m now very confused, because if there’s no right or wrong, I can go two ways… be more functional over design and save time, or keep trying to be OO and be safe from the “wank” as you so put it.

Object oriented programming is the design of your code (spacing, readability) or just safe, memory-leak-free, concurrent with disregard to whether I’m capitalizing my variables correctly or not.

What I thought I understood I now think I’m not to sure. Is it one of those things where it’s different for everybody? Like Marmite?[/quote]

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @The_Outsider The Outsider
item.description:
@The_Outsider wrote:

Ironically, I’m studying a level 2 OOP course in Java…

For the record, I’m using Hyperion, and so what you’re saying is, as long as it’s readable, it doesn’t have to be perfect? Say I take functionality > design now, wouldn’t it ruin the “trend”?

If there’s no right or wrong, and OOP is just a standard if you like, then why is it so misconceived when people post code that isn’t indented perfectly?

I’m now very confused, because if there’s no right or wrong, I can go two ways… be more functional over design and save time, or keep trying to be OO and be safe from the “wank” as you so put it.

Object oriented programming is the design of your code (spacing, readability) or just safe, memory-leak-free, concurrent with disregard to whether I’m capitalizing my variables correctly or not.

What I thought I understood I now think I’m not to sure. Is it one of those things where it’s different for everybody? Like Marmite?

Read full topic

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

The Outsider:

So I should create a getMethod? I also thought using OOP was effectively another way of saying “I’m doing it the proper way, whether more simpler ways work too”.

getMember method you mean, you can’t pass entire methods in Java. Object Oriented Programming (OOP) is just a programming paradigm/methodology; it isn’t right or wrong - and in most cases Functional Programming is most common.

The only reason you’re probably so eager to use an OOP design is due to the amount of wank on this side of the forums regarding it. The most funny part of the aforementioned is that modern RSPS with the exception of a few are very poorly-designed OOP/barely OOP at all.

Perhaps instead of dropping names of paradigms, you should learn to utilize them in situations where they thrive (instead of forcing them or blindly going about development).

Read full topic

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @The_Outsider The Outsider
item.description:
@The_Outsider wrote:

So I should create a getMethod? I also thought using OOP was effectively another way of saying “I’m doing it the proper way, whether more simpler ways work too”.

Read full topic

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“The Outsider, post:7, topic:423297”][quote author=t4 link=topic=525943.msg3830060#msg3830060 date=1322501178]
the final modifier isn’t OO at all; it’s the equivalent of const in C - hence constant.
[/quote]
OO as in I want to be object oriented. I assume if both ways work, then the object oriented way would be not to use final.

Why would you make a variable, unique to each player, static?

I just literally created the class and used static because I need to call it from my Entity class (Class.MY_INT += hit;) and I would get context errors if not.

So as I develop it I shall change accordingly. I like to get things in working order first and then perfect it.[/quote]
instance.getMyInt() / instance.setMyInt(int nint)

Read full topic

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Well, he was trolling in the sense of saving memory. It’s true, but in this case it doesn’t work at all.

And final has nothing to do with object orientation

Read full topic

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @The_Outsider The Outsider
item.description:
@The_Outsider wrote:

t4:

the final modifier isn’t OO at all; it’s the equivalent of const in C - hence constant.

OO as in I want to be object oriented. I assume if both ways work, then the object oriented way would be not to use final.

zyle1992:

Why would you make a variable, unique to each player, static?

I just literally created the class and used static because I need to call it from my Entity class (Class.MY_INT += hit;) and I would get context errors if not.

So as I develop it I shall change accordingly. I like to get things in working order first and then perfect it.

Edit: and I didn’t even know it saves memory?

Read full topic

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

zyle1992:

Why would you make a variable, unique to each player, static?

To Save Memory : - )

item.title: Attribute "final"
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

You’re correct, if you use final it means the object should NEVER change. Don’t use final in this case.

Read full topic
